channel.title: Carl Barrdahl
channel.description: Carl Barrdahl - web developer based in Gothenburg, Sweden

item.title: Building a portfolio part 1
item.description: Setup GatsbyJS Update in and manifest options for the plugin . Deploy to GitHub pages Add deploy script to The argument is needed…
item.content:encoded:
Setup GatsbyJS

npx gatsby new my-blog-starter https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-blog

Update siteMetaData in gatsby-config.js and manifest options for the plugin gatsby-plugin-manifest.

Deploy to GitHub pages

npm install gh-pages --save-dev

Add deploy script to package.json

{
  "scripts": {
    "deploy": "gatsby build --prefix-paths && gh-pages -d public"
  }
}

The --prefix-paths argument is needed because the website is in a folder in GitHub so add your reponame to gatsby-config.js.

module.exports = {
  pathPrefix: "/<reponame>",
}

You can now deploy to Github pages by running npm run deploy

Add projects

Querying project pages

First we need to add a new plugin to gatsby-config.js so we can query the project pages.

plugins: [
  ...
  {
    resolve: `gatsby-source-filesystem`,
    options: {
      path: `${__dirname}/content/projects`,
      name: `projects`
    }
  },
...
]

Adding content and listing projects

We then create the folder /content/projects and add the first project.

mkdir content/projects
touch content/projects/pakt.md

Fill the project file with details about the project.

You’ll notice the project will be listed under Posts. Let’s fix that by opening src/pages/index.js and adding fileAbsolutePath under node in the GraphQL query and then create a function to split based on path.

const filterByType = (type, data) =>
  data.allMarkdownRemark.edges.filter(edge =>
    edge.node.fileAbsolutePath.includes(type)
  )

const posts = filterByType("/blog/", data)
const projects = filterByType("/projects/", data)

Let’s refactor and move our posts and projects to their own components.

Here’s what the ProjectList component looks like:

export default ({ projects }) => (
  <React.Fragment>
    <h2>Projects</h2>
    {projects.map(({ node }) => (
      <div key={node.fields.slug}>
        <h3>
          <Link to={`projects/${node.fields.slug}`}>{node.frontmatter.title}</Link>
        </h3>
        <small>{node.frontmatter.tags.join(", ")}</small>
        <p dangerouslySetInnerHTML={{ __html: node.excerpt }} />
      </div>
    ))}
  </React.Fragment>
)

Project page template

Unless we want to use the same template for our project details page we need to handle that.

First, let’s create a new template by just copying the blog post. Don’t forget to update the class name and export otherwise it will crash.

cp src/templates/blog-post.js src/templates/project-page.js

By including the file path in our GraphQL query we can then render a different template based on which folder contains the markdown file.

First we update the createPages function in gatsby-node.js

# add fileAbsolutePath to the query
...
edges {
  node {
    fileAbsolutePath
    ...

Then define the templates in the createPages function in gatsby-node.js.

const templates = {
  blog: path.resolve(`./src/templates/blog-post.js`),
  projects: path.resolve(`./src/templates/project-page.js`)
}

And resolve the template based on the file path and update the page path:

const [ , contentPath ] = post.node.fileAbsolutePath
  .split("/content")[1]
  .split("/")

createPage({
  path: [ contentPath, post.node.fields.slug ].join(""),
  component: templates[contentPath],
  context: {
    slug: post.node.fields.slug,
    previous,
    next
  }
})

item.title: b0tt0
item.description: An e-commerce platform where users explore nearby connected vendors (restaurants, food trucks, bars, venues, etc) and place orders and…
item.content:encoded: An e-commerce platform where users explore nearby connected vendors (restaurants, food trucks, bars, venues, etc) and place orders and follow updates through push notifications. Vendors see incoming orders and can push them through an order flow to send updates to users

item.title: Pakt
item.description: Pakt is a platform where users can create and share contracts. Documents are uniquely identified with a hash of its content to ensure…
item.content:encoded:
Pakt is a platform where users can create and share contracts. Documents are uniquely identified with a hash of its content to ensure everyone signs the same copy and no tampering is done. Signing and verification of users identity is done with BankID which is the leading electronic identification app in Sweden.

Other services can easily be integrated by specifying webhooks that gets triggered when changes occur in the system.

Future improvements could include adding Swish (similar to BankID but for sms payments) to add costs to creating documents or signatures. Users could also be notified by sms when contracts are assigned or new signatures created to connected contract.

Some documents might be sensitive to store on central servers. In that case something like ipfs could be used to store the documents and then secure them with smart contracts on a blockchain, Ethereum for instance.

Screenshots

Contracts are easily created by dragging a document to upload (or browsing) and filling out the details. Start and end date for contract validity can be set and participants can be added by entering their email.

Documents are embedded to easily be read without need of downloading. Future improvements can include templates to dynamically generate documents based on data.

Sign contract by entering your SSN and open app on mobile. QR code can be added for a more secure (and convenient) signing experience.

All users uploaded and signed contracts are listed.

Contract in screenshots from https://plainfreelancecontract.com/

item.title: Swisher
item.description: Light-weight progressive webapp that lets you generate a Swish (swedish sms payment app) QR code. This makes payments easier as you don’t…
item.content:encoded:
Light-weight progressive webapp that lets you generate a Swish (swedish sms payment app) QR code. This makes payments easier as you don’t have to type or browse phone numbers. Pretty useful when splitting bills among a bunch of people.

Enter your phone number, the amount and an optional message and a QR code is generated to be scanned from the Swish app.

Sensitive data is encrypted in the URL using AES with an optional key. No data is sent to any server.

Screenshots
